title: Persian Qanats: Underground Water Highways
description: A quick, practical guide to Persian Qanats: Underground Water Highways.

hook.text: Persians built underground water tunnels 3,000 years ago that still supply Iranian cities today. They're called qanats.

buildup.text: A qanat taps groundwater at a mountain aquifer and channels it through a sloping tunnelâ€”up to 70 kmâ€”using gravity.

discovery.text: Vertical shafts every 20-30 meters provide air and maintenance access. From above, they look like desert crater lines.

twist.text: Underground flow stops evaporation. In deserts where surface water vanishes in hours, qanats deliver with zero loss.

climax.text: Over 50,000 qanats were built across Iran. At peak, they irrigated more farmland than all modern dams combined.

punchline.text: Ancient tunnels still outperform modern dams in deserts.

quiz.question: What key advantage do qanats have over surface canals in desert climates?
